PRE-MARKET AUSTRALIA, JAPAN AND SOUTH KOREA STOCK NEWS: APRA issues guidance to banks and insurers; Japan cabinet approves JPY 108tln stimulus plan
content:
AUSTRALIA

Austal (ASB AT) - Co. affirms FY20 EBIT of a minimum AUD 110mln and rev. of at least AUD 1.9bln, while it maintains its dividend. (Newswires)

Bank of Queensland (BOQ AT) - Co. reports H1 net cash profit AUD 151mln vs. Prev. AUD 167mln Y/Y, defers dividend payment. (Newswires)

Insurance Australia (IAG AT) - Co. CEO Harmer is to retire by year-end and CFO Hawkins has been named Deputy CEO. (Newswires)

Macquarie Group (MQG AT) - Co. said it will consider the APRA letter in respect to FY20 dividend amounts. (Newswires)

McMillan Shakespeare (MMS AT) - Co. will temporarily partially or fully stand down staff in areas with a decline in workload. (Newswires)

NAB (NAB AT) - Co. notes it will take APRA guidance when determining its H1 dividend. (Newswires)

QBE Insurance (QBE AT) - Co. confirms payment of final dividend of AUD 0.27 per share as scheduled after considering APRA guidance. (Newswires)

Seven Group (SVW AT) - Co. withdraws FY20 guidance but will be paying an interim dividend, (Newswires)

Treasury Wine Estates (TWE AT) - Co. eyes potential AUD 10bln demerger of its Penfolds business by end-2021. (Newswires)

Virgin Australia (VAH AT) - Co. CEO said we are not looking for a bailout but need assistance to bridge through the crisis to restore confidence in the airline and is flexible on the form of assistance the government may provide. (Newswires)

Financials - Australia regulator APRA issued a letter to banks in which it noted that banks and insurers have a critical role to play in supporting household, businesses and broader economy during the significant disruption from the coronavirus outbreak, while it expects ADIs and insurers to limit discretionary capital distributions in the months ahead and to ensure they use buffers as well as maintain capacity to continue to lend and underwrite insurance which includes prudent reductions in dividends and need to preserve capacity to prioritize critical activities. In related news, APRA has temporarily suspended issuances of new banking, insurance and superannuation licences which could last for at least 6 months. (Newswires)

 

JAPAN

Hitachi Construction Machinery (6305 JT) - Co. is to halt 4 plants in Japan due to the coronavirus. (Newswires)

Mitsubishi Motors (7211 JT) - Co. will lay off as much as 6.5k workers in Japan. (Nikkei)

Nissan (7201 JT) - Co. said it absolutely plans to rehire current US workers on furlough. (Newswires)

Rakuten (4755 JT) - Co. begins low-cost mobile phone service in Japan. (Newswires)

ROUND ONE (4680 JT) - Co. March same store sales fell 24.1% Y/Y, while it will extend temporary store closures in Japan to May 6th. (Newswires)

SCSK Corp (9719 JT) - Co. may report an FY oper. profit increase of 9% Y/Y. (Newswires)

SoftBank (9984 JT) - WeWork sues Co. for reneging on tender offer. (Nikkei)

Sugi Holdings (7649 JT) - Co. FY net JPY 10.8bln vs. Prev. JPY 19.7bln Y/Y. (Newswires)

Other News - Japanese government has approved the JPY 108.2tln emergency economic stimulus package with JPY 39.5tln spending as expected, while PM Abe declared a State of Emergency as expected in Tokyo, Osaka, alongside five other prefectures for one month amid the coronavirus. (Newswires)

 

SOUTH KOREA

Doosan Heavy (034020 KS) - Co. creditors have requested Co. offload assets as part of its restructuring. (Newswires)

Hynix Semiconductor (000660 KS) - Judge ruled in favour of the Co. in patent suit with Netlist. (Newswires)

Korean Air Lines (003490 KS) - Co. will begin a 6-month work stoppage for 70% of employees from April 16th. (Newswires)

subject: US President Trump says US being hit hard now and it will be a painful week but also notes we see glimmers of hope
DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US CDC said COVID-19 cases rose 13% to 374,329 (prev. +8.5% at 330,891) and the death toll rose +35% to 12,064 (prev. +17% at 8,910). (Newswires)

Italy COVID-19 cases rose 2.3% to 135,586 (prev. +2.8% at 132,547), death toll rose 3.7% to 17,127 (prev. +4% at 16,523). (Newswires)

France COVID-19 cases rose 3.9% to 101,787 (prev. +5.6% at 98,010), death toll rose 15.9% to 10,328 (prev. +10.3% at 8,911). (Newswires)

China’s Wuhan has lifted the outbound travel restrictions. (Xinhua)

US Treasury is preparing to ask Congress for an additional USD 200bln for the small business lending programme, according to sources. (Washington Post)

UK Cabinet Minister Gove is now in self-isolation and remains well, with the isolation due to a family member displaying virus symptoms, according to ITV's Brand. (Twitter)

 

ASIA-PAC

Japanese government has approved the JPY 108.2tln emergency economic stimulus package with JPY 39.5tln spending as expected, while PM Abe declared a State of Emergency as expected in Tokyo, Osaka, alongside five other prefectures for one month amid the coronavirus. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

ECB announced a package of temporary collateral easing measures and adopts an unprecedented set of collateral measures to mitigate the tightening of financial conditions across the euro area, while it decided to accept Greek government bonds as collateral. The temporary increase in the Eurosystem’s risk tolerance is in order to support credit to the economy, while the ECB eased the conditions for the use of credit claims as collateral and adopted a general reduction of collateral valuation haircuts. Furthermore, the ECB will assess further measures to temporarily mitigate the effect on counterparties’ collateral availability from rating downgrades. (Newswires)

ECB's Makhlouf said the coronavirus crisis requires unprecedented, forceful, coordinated and ambitious actions by all EU governments but noted that helicopter money is not the solution to the coronavirus crises. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

US Private Inventory Crude Stocks (Apr 3) +11.9mln vs. Exp. +9.3mln (Prev. +10.5mln). (Newswires)

There were initial reports that Saudi Arabia and Russia were coming closer to an agreement on an output deal according to delegates and that OPEC+ oil cut volume for Thursday's meeting is dependent on the amount US, Canada, Brazil and others propose to cut according to OPEC sources which noted the baseline for oil cuts is yet to be agreed upon. It was also reported there was no consensus between Russia and Saudi Arabia as of yet and all will be decided at Thursday's OPEC+ meeting, while other reports stated that OPEC+ is discussing an output cut for three months beginning in May and an OPEC delegate said current options being considered range from a 10mln BPD cut to no cut. (Newswires/RIA/TASS)

Saudi Cabinet stated its call for the OPEC+ meeting is an extension to its efforts to achieve a balanced and stable market. (Newswires)         

US Energy Secretary Brouillette will partake in the virtual G20 meeting on Friday to discuss stabilising the world oil market. (Newswires)

EIA STEO: Cuts 2020 world oil demand growth forecast by 5.6mln BPD to 5.23mln BPD and raised 2021 forecast by 4.68mln BPD to 6.41mln BPD. (Newswires)

A Bipartisan group of US lawmakers have introduced a bill providing USD 3bln to purchase oil to fill the SPR. (Newswires)

Texas regulators reiteratd they will consider curtailing oil output at the April 14th meeting in an attempt to stem the price collapse. (Newswires)

 

US

Fed’s Kaplan (Voter, Dove) said the US economy is likely to go through a significant adjustment after the COVID-19 pandemic recedes as businesses evaluate how demand has been reshaped. (Newswires)

 

MARKET RECAP

The tone of trading was risk-on for the most part. Early doors, the risk stars were aligning (Treasuries bear-steepened, dollar down, oil up, equity futures rallying), although the conviction eased throughout the session, and the situation is a little more tentative as the Asia day beckons, SPX even entered negative territory just before the close. The main themes are OPEC, and the challenges around engineering a globally coordinated supply cut this week (meeting on Thursday; G20 energy ministers meet on Friday). European players are also on the lookout for an update from the Eurogroup, which is expected to rubber-stamp a massive stimulus package that could be worth up to 5% of the bloc’s GDP. US equities are now up about 25% from the March trough, with the slate of coronavirus updates providing some encouragement; the Wuhan province is also starting to open up in China, potentially offering statisticians some insight into how lockdowns may play out in the US and in Europe. Some desks, however, suggested that the US upside could be a result of liquidity, volatility, positioning conditions which are exacerbating moves, given the market a choppy feel. Boeing (BA) announced it is to temporarily suspend its 787 operations at the South Carolina facility. Exxon Mobil (XOM) cut its 2020 CapEx by 30% and OpEx by 15%, noting the largest share of CapEx reductions will be in the Permian Basin. XOM maintained its long-term outlook. 3M (MMM) and the Trump administration resolved its dispute, while MMM is to import 166.5mln respirators over three months. Kraft Heinz (KHC) expects Q1 net sales growth of 3%, above analyst expectations for a sales decline. AT&T (T) will continue to pay quarterly dividends and it has entered a new USD 5.5bln term loan agreement with banks. Stocks that have been heavily hit of late due to COVID saw a decent rally on Tuesday; travel names were bid, with cruise operators (CCL, NCLH, RCL) up ~20% while Airlines (AAL, DAL, UAL, LUV) were up 10-15% in the morning. Note, the opposite was seen with some of the winners from COVID-19 fallout, which endured some losses; Slack (WORK), Zoom (ZM) and DocuSign (DOCU) in negative territory. Cypress Semiconductor (CY) and Infineon (IFX GY, IFNNY) received antitrust clearance in China, expects deal to be completed April 16th. Abercrombie and Fitch (ANF) and Ralph Laruen (RL) furlough in store workers. Activision (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) were rated as new overweight and new equal weight, respectively, at Wells Fargo. Boeing's (BA) 737 MAX regulatory test flight has reportedly been delayed to May, according to AFP citing sources. iQIYI (IQ) was named a new short at Muddy Waters, who after working with Wolfpack Research believes the co. is a fraud. Note, Baidu (BIDU) own a hefty stake in the name. SPX -0.16% at 2659, NDX -0.40% at 8049, DJIA -0.12% at 22654.

The Treasury curve continued to bear-steepen on Tuesday, as the cocktail of an extended risk rally, further issuance (both government and corporates) and scaled-back Fed bond buying weighed. The selling began at the tail-end of the APAC session, as stock futures gained traction heading into the European day. The steepener was further supported by comments from NEC Director Kudlow, who said the Treasury was aiming to reopen the 20-year bond amid the virus outbreak – Treasury Sec. Mnuchin has made similar comments in the past. Germany announcing plans for a new 15-year bond syndication, which pressured EGBs, lending an offer across the Atlantic. Meanwhile, the Fed continues to remove the stabilisers, purchasing a reduced clip of USD 50bln for a second day this week, although bid/ask spreads remain tight with decent volume in the futures, indicative of healthy market depth, as opposed to the lack of such back in March when the Fed stepped in. Duration was hit further by concession ahead of the 10-year auction reopening, where the Treasury sold USD 25bln, tailing by 0.7bps, marking the lowest ever high rate on a 10-year auction; the auction otherwise printed results similar to the six-auction averages, covered 2.43x and dealers taking 27.6%. Bidders in the Treasury complex were also dissuaded as the corporate issuance bonanza continued, with nine investment grade issuers on Tuesday (versus eleven on Monday), and even a few high-yield deals coming to the market; Qatar was out with a three-part USD 10bln issue, only widened the supply for participants to digest. US T-note futures (m0) settle 16 ticks lower at 137-29.

subject: Newsquawk US Market Wrap - April 7th: Risk rally fades in late trade ahead of Eurogroup, OPEC
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • SNAPSHOT: Equities down, Treasuries down, Dollar down, Crude down.
  • REARVIEW: New York and Italy cases continue to show signs of a plateau; Pelosi calls for at least another USD 1trln in new bill; ECB to loosen collateral requirements, now accepts Greek debt.
  • COMING UP: Data: Japanese Machinery Orders, EIAs. Events: FOMC Minutes & Banxico Minutes. Supply: UK, Germany & US.

MARKET WRAP

The tone of trading was risk-on for the most part. Early doors, the risk stars were aligning (Treasuries bear-steepened, dollar down, oil up, equity futures rallying), although the conviction eased throughout the session, and the situation is a little more tentative as the Asia day beckons, SPX even entered negative territory just before the close. The main themes are OPEC, and the challenges around engineering a globally coordinated supply cut this week (meeting on Thursday; G20 energy ministers meet on Friday). European players are also on the lookout for an update from the Eurogroup, which is expected to rubber-stamp a massive stimulus package that could be worth up to 5% of the bloc’s GDP. US equities are now up about 25% from the March trough, with the slate of coronavirus updates providing some encouragement; the Wuhan province is also starting to open up in China, potentially offering statisticians some insight into how lockdowns may play out in the US and in Europe. Some desks, however, suggested that the US upside could be a result of liquidity, volatility, positioning conditions which are exacerbating moves, given the market a choppy feel.

VIRUS CASE COUNT

WORLDWIDE CASES 1,414,710, DEATHS 81,248, RECOVERED 301,304.

Figures provided as of Tuesday (via worldometer website) against Monday:

  • US total cases 388,757 (prev. 367,004), death toll 12,400 (prev. 10,871).
  • ITALY total cases 135,586 (prev. 132,547), death toll 17,127 (prev. 16,523).
  • SPAIN total cases 140,511 (prev. 136,675), death toll 13,987 (prev. 13,341).
  • GERMANY total cases 107,458 (prev. 103,375), death toll 1,983 (prev. 1,810).
  • CHINA total cases 81,740 (prev. 81,708), death toll 3,331 (prev. 3,331).
  • FRANCE total cases 109,069 (prev. 98,010), death toll 10,328 (prev. 8,911).
  • UK total cases 55,242 (prev. 51,608), death toll 6,159 (prev. 5,373).
  • SWITZERLAND total cases 22,253 (prev. 21,657), death toll 821 (prev. 765).
  • NETHERLANDS total cases 19,580 (prev. 18,803), death toll 2,101 (prev. 1,867).
  • CANADA total cases 17,840 (prev. 16,667), death toll 375 (prev. 323).
  • SOUTH KOREA total cases 10,331 (prev. 10,284), death toll 192 (prev. 186).

Note figures are provided via worldometer thus there may be some discrepancies on figures provided against those stated from individual states.

EUROPE

EUROGROUP: The post-meeting press conference has been delayed, and no set time provided for the rescheduled conference. The meeting was to discuss a coordinated funding response to address the COVID-19 fall out, which could see measures worth 4.5-5% of GDP.  Sides have recently failed to reach a consensus on a bloc-wide response, with many Southern nations calling for joint bond issuance to finance any response, which had met opposition from Northern members. However, although ‘Coronabonds’ are seemingly a non-starter for now, the group may strike a deal on using the ESM bailout fund to extend credit lines with flexible conditions. Recent press reports have suggested that a three-pronged proposal is being discussed, consisting of healthcare funding via the ESM of EUR 200-240bln, EIB credit guarantees worth EUR 200bln, and an EU-wide short-shift or partial unemployment scheme from the EC worth EUR 100bln. Deutsche Bank said that a package of this size would be an impressive 4.5% of GDP and circumvents the need for Coronabonds at this stage. “The details will matter and the three elements are only temporary,” DB writes, “as the risk of a protracted pandemic rises, so too does the need to follow up this plan with a centralised demand stimulus package, for example, a large-scale EIB investment programme. So, a big meeting to watch.

UK PM JOHNSON: After being admitted into an Intensive Care Unit (ICU) on Monday, UK PM Johnson was stable overnight and he did not need a mechanical ventilator, according to government spokespeople, but he did receive standard oxygen treatment and was said to be breathing without assistance. Johnson asked Foreign Secretary Raab to deputise him; Raab led the coronavirus briefing on Tuesday, while Downing Street remains fully operational. NOTE: an FT journalist, citing sources,  had reported that the PM was set to come out of the ICU, but her tweet was then removed; the reporter clarified the tweet was accurate, she just removed it due to the heavy attention it received.

GERMANY: Germany’s top institutes expect the German economy to contract by 4.2% in 2020 and by 5.8% in 2021. Furthermore, the Ifo Institute stated that industrial production in Germany is set to plummet - Ifo index for production expectations dropped in March from +2.0 to -20.8, on this they assume the development is underestimated given the survey period; marks the most drastic slump since the survey began.

NORTH AMERICA

STIMULUS: US House Speaker Pelosi told Democrats she wants the next stimulus bill to be at least USD 1tln, while she is said to be seeking more directs payments and small business loans in the next bill, too. Meanwhile, President Trump noted businesses have applied for more than USD 40bln in relief loans, and also that USD 30bln in hospital aid is going out this week. Trump added that his administration could do a second round of direct payments to Americans. Regarding the small business lending programme, the Treasury has asked Congress for an additional USD 200bln funding; the recently passed USD 2trln stimulus package contained USD 349bl for the small business lending programme. The latest request comes amid strong demand just several days into the initial programme. Elsewhere, Senate Majority Leader McConnell aims to pass a Paycheck Protection Program increase by unanimous consent on Thursday.

LOCKDOWN: President Trump said the US has made tremendous progress on therapeutics, and that the administration wants to try to be able to lift restrictions on April 30th. NEC Director Kudlow said that the administration is looking to reopen the economy as soon as health experts give the green light.

APAC

JAPAN: PM Abe declared a State of Emergency in Tokyo, Osaka, alongside five other prefectures for one month; additionally, Japanese government has approved the JPY 108.2trl emergency economic stimulus package with JPY 39.5trln spending, as expected.

CENTRAL BANKS

ECB announced a package of temporary (but unprecedented) collateral easing measures to mitigate the tightening of financial conditions across the Euro area, and support credit to the economy. Crucially, the measures included the acceptance of Greek government bonds as collateral. Further, the ECB has eased the conditions for the use of credit claims as collateral and has adopted a general reduction of collateral valuation haircuts. The central bank said it will assess further measures to temporarily mitigate the effect on counterparties’ collateral availability from rating downgrades.

RBA: The central bank left all policy settings unchanged (rates at 0.25% and reaffirmed the 3-year yield target at 0.25%), and pledged that if conditions continue to improve, it is likely that smaller and less frequent purchases of government bonds will be required. But the RBA also stated that it will do what is necessary to achieve its 3-year yield target of 0.25%, and that target is expected to remain in place until progress has been made on the labour market and inflation.

FED: FOMC Meeting Minutes to be released at 1400 ET/1900 BST on 8th April 2020. On the 3rd March, the Fed cut rates by 50bps in an emergency move. And then on 15th March weekend meeting, the Fed took further aggressive steps, slashing rates by 100bps to 0.25% in its second inter-meeting rate move; it also committed to at least USD 700bln of QE, eased regulatory pressure on banks to free up capital, and announced dollar swap lines with other central banks. The timing of both announcements and the scope of the measures was a surprise -- in effect, it was the Fed’s ‘whatever it takes’ commitment to ensure the smooth functioning of markets amid the virus fallout. NOTE: It is not clear whether the release of the minutes will cover both meetings or just the latter; it is also unclear that if the minutes do cover both meetings, whether the release will be in two separate documents, or one aggregated one. Analysts at Nomura, however, have stated that the minutes will cover actions taken at both meetings. Since then, it has flooded the market with liquidity, resulting in the premium for dollars easing. Its balance sheet has ballooned to by USD 1.5trln to a new record high USD 5.86trln, and it has seen wide take-up of its liquidity facilities from banks and other central banks. The meeting minutes are unlikely to contain anything to spook markets, given that it has rolled out measures to assuage market concerns, and will likely reiterate its pledge to support the financial system. Analysts think the discussions will likely show most participants backing the use of the Fed’s toolkit aggressively, as COVID-19 outbreak began weighing on activity. The minutes may, however, feel stale. Since the 15th March meeting, the Fed has announced other measures (boosted QE and MBS purchases on 23/Mar, expanded repo for foreign central banks on 31/Mar, and also announced six further facilities, including the commercial paper facility). Discussions around these themes will likely appear in the next meeting minutes for the 28-29th April meeting, analysts believe. NOTE: Fed Chair Powell will be delivering remarks via weblink on Thursday, and will likely emphasise the themes within the minutes.

CRUDE

WTI (K0) SETTLES USD 2.45 LOWER AT USD 23.63/BBL; BRENT (M0) SETTLES USD 1.18 LOWER AT USD 31.87/BBL

Front-month crude futures reversed earlier tentative gains as participants gear up for Thursday’s OPEC+ (plus) meeting. OPEC delegate reports suggest that Saudi and Russia are coming closer to an output deal; however, Russian press reports have subsequently pushed back on this notion, stating all will be decided at Thursday’s OPEC call. Russian press reported that the group could cut for three-months beginning in May, which resulted in some downside in crude futures, potentially as the market could be after a longer deal, and something more immediate. Meanwhile, as OPEC+ calls on other global producer to contribute to the cuts, US President Trump said that nobody has asked him to reduce US output, and he would decide when or if OPEC asks, adding that US producers had cut automatically as a reaction to the market. Note, OPEC sources have doubled-down on the demand, saying the volume of reductions is dependent on the amount proposed by the US, Canada and Brazil. Meanwhile, the price rout continues to be felt across the US, where major Exxon Mobil (XOM) cut its 2020 capex by 30%, saying the largest share of reductions will come from the Permian Basin.

SPR: A Bipartisan group of US lawmakers introduced a bill providing USD 3bln to purchase oil to fill the SPR, which has a spare capacity of 77mln barrels. The previous plan to fill the SPR was dropped as there was a lack of funding in the recent stimulus bill. However, since then the Department of Energy announced it would lease an initial 30mln space in the SPR to oil firms, while noting it intends to make an additional 47mln barrels available to lease later on, which would fill the 77mln bbls of spare capacity. The move comes amid a lack of storage space after the price of oil collapsed. The latest issue is reportedly with Marathon Petroleum (MPC), who are to reduce production by 25% at its 585k BPD Galveston Bay refinery amid a lack of storage, according to sources.

CRUDE INVENTORIES: Looking ahead, the weekly US energy inventories draw attention with the private data release aftermarket on Tuesday; current expectations (bbls) see crude stocks building by 9.3mln, distillate building by 1.4mln and gasoline stocks seen building 4.3mln.

EIA STEO: Cuts its 2020 world oil demand growth forecast by 5.6mln BPD to 5.23mln BPD, raised 2021 forecast by 4.68mln BPD to 6.41mln BPD. Cut its 2020 US crude output by 470k BPD (prev. +760k BPD) to 11.76mln BPD, cut its 2021 output forecast by 730k BPD (prev. -330k BPD) to 11.03mln BPD.

FIXED INCOME

US T-NOTE FUTURES (M0) SETTLE 16 TICKS LOWER AT 137-29

The Treasury curve continued to bear-steepen on Tuesday, as the cocktail of an extended risk rally, further issuance (both government and corporates) and scaled-back Fed bond buying weighed. The selling began at the tail-end of the APAC session, as stock futures gained traction heading into the European day. The steepener was further supported by comments from NEC Director Kudlow, who said the Treasury was aiming to reopen the 20-year bond amid the virus outbreak – Treasury Sec. Mnuchin has made similar comments in the past. Germany announcing plans for a new 15-year bond syndication, which pressured EGBs, lending an offer across the Atlantic. Meanwhile, the Fed continues to remove the stabilisers, purchasing a reduced clip of USD 50bln for a second day this week, although bid/ask spreads remain tight with decent volume in the futures, indicative of healthy market depth, as opposed to the lack of such back in March when the Fed stepped in. Bidders in the Treasury complex were also dissuaded as the corporate issuance bonanza continued, with nine investment grade issuers on Tuesday (versus eleven on Monday), and even a few high-yield deals coming to the market; Qatar was out with a three-part USD 10bln issue, only widened the supply for participants to digest.

EQUITIES

CLOSING LEVELS: SPX -0.16% at 2659, NDX -0.40% at 8049, DJIA -0.12% at 22654.

SECTORS: Materials +2.42%, Energy +2%, Consumer Discretionary +1.2%, Real Estate +0.1%, Industrials -0.2%, Health Care -0.9%, IT -1.05%, Communication Svs. -1.15%, Consumer Staples -1.2%, Utilities -1.2%.

STOCK SPECIFICS: Boeing (BA) announced it is to temporarily suspend its 787 operations at the South Carolina facility. Exxon Mobil (XOM) cut its 2020 CapEx by 30% and OpEx by 15%, noting the largest share of CapEx reductions will be in the Permian Basin. XOM maintained its long-term outlook. 3M (MMM) and the Trump administration resolved its dispute, while MMM is to import 166.5mln respirators over three months. Kraft Heinz (KHC) expects Q1 net sales growth of 3%, above analyst expectations for a sales decline. AT&T (T) will continue to pay quarterly dividends and it has entered a new USD 5.5bln term loan agreement with banks. Stocks that have been heavily hit of late due to COVID saw a decent rally on Tuesday; travel names were bid, with cruise operators (CCL, NCLH, RCL) up ~20% while Airlines (AAL, DAL, UAL, LUV) were up 10-15% in the morning. Note, the opposite was seen with some of the winners from COVID-19 fallout, which endured some losses; Slack (WORK), Zoom (ZM) and DocuSign (DOCU) in negative territory. Abercrombie and Fitch (ANF) and Ralph Laruen (RL) furlough in store workers. Activision (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) were rated as new overweight and new equal weight, respectively, at Wells Fargo. Boeing's (BA) 737 MAX regulatory test flight has reportedly been delayed to May, according to AFP citing sources. iQIYI (IQ) was named a new short at Muddy Waters, who after working with Wolfpack Research believes the co. is a fraud. Note, Baidu (BIDU) own a hefty stake in the name.           

FOREX

USD: The dollar was down amid risk on conditions; risk sensitive FX (AUD, NZD, CAD, GBP all firmer) and EMFX was buoyed. The dollar selling saw DXY fall back beneath the 100.0 handle, to lows of 99.75. ING said USD funding fears may also be declining further as the IMF is apparently working on a repo facility to assist smaller economies with USD liquidity issues.

GBP: Was a beneficiary of an improved risk backdrop, while UK PM Johnson’s condition is stable, adding some support. Analysts at SocGen note the GBPUSD 200 dma at 1.2660-1.2720 as likely to be the next level of resistance if the bounce were to continue from the lows, if not a near term support would be 1.1950.

EUR: The single currency was firmer today and briefly crossed 1.09 to the upside although now resides around the psychological level as participants await an update from the Eurogroup on its coordinated response to tackle the coronavirus.

JPY, XAU: As expected Japanese PM Abe declared a state of emergency over the coronavirus, as was hinted at yesterday. Abe also approved the JPY 108.2trln emergency economic stimulus package with JPY 39.5trln spending as expected. Despite the risk on feel today, USDJPY traded lower as dollar saw outflows as dollar scarcity normalises. USDJPY traded around the 109.00 figure. JPMorgan’s analysts stated that it has “reduced the vast majority of its USDJPY shorts yesterday as we feel that the idiosyncratic local dynamics are not playing out as we have expected,” and adds, that it remains on the side line for now looking to trade more opportunistically, highlighting the first support at 108.70/80 with 108.10/20 below that, while 109.25/35 remains resistance ahead of 110.00/10. Meanwhile, gold traded in line with risk appetite falling to lows of 1,643 from highs of 1,671 after solid gains yesterday despite signs supply shortages may ease in the coming weeks in Switzerland and the risk rally.

AUD, NZD: The Aussie dollar rose in wake of the RBA announcement. Although the central bank left all policy settings unchanged, it pledged that if conditions continue to improve, it is likely that smaller and less frequent purchases of government bonds will be required. But the RBA also stated that it will do what is necessary to achieve its 3-year yield target of 0.25%, and that target is expected to remain in place until progress has been made on the labour market and inflation. The Aussie also benefitted from an improved risk appetite which helped cyclical currencies perform well in general, although AUD outperformed and briefly crossed 0.6200 against the buck, a level it resides around heading into ASIA-PAC trade. The kiwi benefitted from the positive risk tone today albeit not to the same extent as the Aussie, perhaps capped by dismal confidence data which was -70% from a prior -20%.

CAD: The Loonie was another cyclical to benefit from risk appetite (albeit less so than GBP, AUD and NZD as crude prices were subdued ahead of Thursday’s OPEC+ call). Scotiabank said the market finds itself softer and edging below the base of its recent consolidation/21-day MA at 1.4137 (now immediate resistance) and added that it looks for a retest of the low 1.39s in the near-term.

EMFX: The dollar weakness and improved risk appetite see EM’s perform well, particularly the MXN and ZAR. Mexico inflation data (Mar.) did little to impact the Peso; core inflation ticked down slightly in line with expectations while 12-month inflation ticked down to 3.25% from 3.7% while headline inflation deflated slightly.

subject: TREASURY WRAP: US T-Note futures (M0) settle 16 ticks lower at 137-29
analysis_details: The Treasury curve continued to bear-steepen on Tuesday, as the cocktail of an extended risk rally, further issuance (both government and corporates) and scaled-back Fed bond buying weighed. The selling began at the tail-end of the APAC session, as stock futures gained traction heading into the European day. The steepener was further supported by comments from NEC Director Kudlow, who said the Treasury was aiming to reopen the 20-year bond amid the virus outbreak – Treasury Sec. Mnuchin has made similar comments in the past. Germany announcing plans for a new 15-year bond syndication, which pressured EGBs, lending an offer across the Atlantic. Meanwhile, the Fed continues to remove the stabilizers, purchasing a reduced clip of USD 50bln for a second day this week, although bid/ask spreads remain tight with decent volume in the futures, indicative of healthy market depth, as opposed to the lack of such back in March when the Fed stepped in. Duration was hit further by concession ahead of the 10-year auction reopening, where the Treasury sold USD 25bln, tailing by 0.7bps, marking the lowest ever high rate on a 10-year auction; the auction otherwise printed results similar to the six-auction averages, covered 2.43x and dealers taking 27.6%. Bidders in the Treasury complex were also dissuaded as the corporate issuance bonanza continued, with nine investment grade issuers on Tuesday (versus eleven on Monday), and even a few high-yield deals coming to the market; Qatar was out with a three-part USD 10bln issue, only widened the supply for participants to digest.

subject: CRUDE WRAP: WTI (K0) settles USD 2.45 lower at USD 23.63/bbl; Brent (M0) settles USD 1.18 lower at USD 31.87/bbl
analysis_details:
• Front-month crude futures reversed earlier tentative gains as participants gear up for Thursday’s OPEC+ (plus) meeting. OPEC delegate reports suggest that Saudi and Russia are coming closer to an output deal; however, Russian press reports have subsequently pushed back on this notion, stating all will be decided at Thursday’s OPEC call. Russian press reported that the group could cut for three-months beginning in May, which resulted in some downside in crude futures, potentially as the market could be after a longer deal, and something more immediate. Meanwhile, as OPEC+ calls on other global producer to contribute to the cuts, US President Trump said that nobody has asked him to reduce US output, and he would decide when or if OPEC asks, adding that US producers had cut automatically as a reaction to the market. Note, OPEC sources have doubled-down on the demand, saying the volume of reductions is dependent on the amount proposed by the US, Canada and Brazil. Meanwhile, the price rout continues to be felt across the US, where major Exxon Mobil (XOM) cut its 2020 capex by 30%, saying the largest share of reductions will come from the Permian Basin. Looking ahead, the weekly US energy inventories draw attention with the private data release aftermarket on Tuesday; current expectations (bbls) see crude stocks building by 9.3mln, distillate building by 1.4mln and gasoline stocks seen building 4.3mln.
  • SPR: A Bipartisan group of US lawmakers have introduced a bill providing USD 3bln to purchase oil to fill the SPR, which has a spare capacity of 77mln barrels. The previous plan to fill the SPR was dropped as there was a lack of funding in the recent stimulus bill. However, since then the Department of Energy announced it would lease an initial 30mln space in the SPR to oil firms, while noting it intends to make an additional 47mln barrels available to lease later on, which would fill the 77mln bbls of spare capacity. The move comes amid a lack of storage space after the price of oil collapsed. The latest issue is reportedly with Marathon Petroleum (MPC), who are to reduce production by 25% at its 585k BPD Galveston Bay refinery amid a lack of storage, according to sources.
  • CRUDE INVENTORIES: Looking ahead, the weekly US energy inventories draw attention with the private data release aftermarket on Tuesday; current expectations (bbls) see crude stocks building by 9.3mln, distillate building by 1.4mln and gasoline stocks seen building 4.3mln.
  • EIA STEO: Cuts its 2020 world oil demand growth forecast by 5.6mln BPD to 5.23mln BPD, raised 2021 forecast by 4.68mln BPD to 6.41mln BPD. Cut its 2020 US crude output by 470k BPD (prev. +760k BPD) to 11.76mln BPD, cut its 2021 output forecast by 730k BPD (prev. -330k BPD) to 11.03mln BPD.

PRIMER: Tuesday's Eurogroup meeting to discuss EU virus response could see measures worth 4.5-5.0%/GDP announced [REPOST]
content:
• Today, the Eurogroup will hold a video conference to discuss a coordinated funding response to address the COVID-19 fallout. The conference was delayed an hour and started at 15:00BST with a press conference initially expected around 19:00BST, the hour delay could see this pushed back to 20:00 BST also.
  • Sides have recently failed to reach a consensus on a bloc-wide response, with many Southern nations calling for joint bond issuance to finance any response, which had met opposition from Northern members.
  • However, although 'Coronabonds' are seemingly a non-starter for now, the group may strike a deal on using the ESM bailout fund to extend credit lines with flexible conditions.
  • Recent press reports have suggested that a three-pronged proposal is being discussed, consisting of healthcare funding via the ESM of EUR 200-240bln, EIB credit guarantees worth EUR 200bln, and an EU-wide short-shift or partial unemployment scheme from the EC worth EUR 100bln.
  • Deutsche Bank said that a package of this size would be an impressive 4.5% of GDP, and circumvents the need for Coronabonds at this stage. "The details will matter and the three elements are only temporary," DB writes, "as the risk of a protracted pandemic rises, so too does the need to follow up this plan with a centralised demand stimulus package, for example, a large-scale EIB investment programme. So a big meeting to watch."

Daily FX Wrap: Buck bows in deference to others and dissipating COVID-19 concerns
content:
USD

Although it is still way too early to declare victory or even a definitive breakthrough in the battle against the global coronavirus pandemic, the mood remains optimistic and certainly less gloomy than it was before the weekend when the daily rate of cases and fatalities in some places was rising exponentially. Indeed, stocks and commodities continue to rebound, with oil also simmering on the prospect of a positive end to the Saudi-Russia spat over crude prices and market share by the end of the week if not Thursday. Hence, high risk/beta/cyclical currencies and assets are maintaining Monday’s recovery momentum to the detriment of safe havens, while the Dollar is also losing out as demand for funding and liquidity continue to normalise. In response, the DXY relinquished 100.000+ status and probed below its month end high (99.948) towards the base of a 100.790-99.754 band before regaining some poise.

AUD 

Off best levels as its US counterpart attempts to find a base, but Aud/Usd is near the apex of wide 0.6207-0.6077 parameters in wake of the RBA standing pat on rates and noting that QE can be tapered when the time is right.

EUR

The Euro has not been able to extend on gains above the 1.0900 handle vs the Buck, but did see some support from the usual fix-related demand vs the Pound around 4 pm London time that supplemented traction from rising Eurozone yields and spread convergence to US Treasuries and UK Gilts.

NZD/CHF/CAD/GBP/JPY

Also retaining their advantage over the Greenback, but down from earlier peaks as broad risk appetite wanes somewhat, with Nzd/Usd back below 0.6000, Usd/Chf bouncing from a brief sub-0.9700 foray, Usd/Cad revisiting 1.4000 vs 1.3945 as oil wavers and Canada’s Ivey PMIs provide even more evidence of the fallout from nCoV. Meanwhile, Cable is trying to consolidate above 1.2300 after the aforementioned Eur/Gbp cross flows that undermined Sterling, but with some positivity emanating from latest reports on the condition of UK PM Johnson. Elsewhere, the Yen is still anchored around 109.00 after Tokyo and 6 other Japanese prefectures entered states of emergency and the Government announced record JGB issuance to fund counter-virus measures.

SCANDI/EM

Another good day at the office for the Scandinavian Kronas and EM currencies, with even the beleaguered Huf getting some respite from pseudo NBH tightening via a ramp up in overnight and 1-week collateralised funding rates to 1.85% from 0.9%.

analysis_details:
• MACRO: The equity party continued through the night as Asian bourses carried on from Monday’s Wall Street gains – which saw SPX rise by ~7% - and continues to support futures in European trade. The Treasury curve continues to bear-steepen, 2s +2bps, while 7s, 10s, and 30s all +5bps – ahead of the 10-year Treasury auction. Crude is trading slightly firmer ahead of Thursday’s OPEC+ meeting, albeit off highs after TASS sources suggested a three-month OPEC+ cut starting in May. Meanwhile, Gold trades subdued, while the DXY has moved lower beneath the 100 figure.
  • SECTOR THEMES: In Europe, the coronavirus-hit names are seeing outperformance as stocks continue a heavy bounce following on from yesterday’s gains, spurred by signs that coronavirus cases could be slowing somewhat. In the US, travel names are bid, with cruise operators (CCL, NCLH, RCL) +20%, while Airlines (AAL, DAL, UAL, LUV) are up 10-15%. Attention on energy is high ahead of OPEC’s emergency meeting on Thursday, with President Trump noting he has not agreed to cut oil production as part of the OPEC+ deal and nor has anybody asked him to, adding US companies have already been cutting output given the current situation. However, the latest reports continue to state production cuts are needed from oil-producing nations, including the US. All sectors open in the green with defensives (XLP, XLU, XLV) at the bottom of the pack although still firmer by 1-2%; Technology also a laggard. Energy and financials lead the gains with the former benefitting from firmer yields.
  • US EQUITY STORIES: Boeing (BA) announced it is to temporarily suspend its 787 operations at the South Carolina facility. Exxon Mobil (XOM) cut its 2020 CapEx by 30% and OpEx by 15%, noting the largest share of CapEx reductions will be in the Permian Basin. XOM maintained its long-term outlook. 3M (MMM) and the Trump administration resolved its dispute, while MMM is to import 166.5mln respirators over three months. Kraft Heinz (KHC) expects Q1 net sales growth of 3%, above analyst expectations for a sales decline. AT&T (T) will continue to pay quarterly dividends and it has entered a new USD 5.5bln term loan agreement with banks. Cypress Semiconductor (CY) and Infineon (IFX GY, IFNNY) received antitrust clearance in China, expects deal to be completed April 16th. Abercrombie and Fitch (ANF) and Ralph Laruen (RL) furlough in store workers. Activision (ATVI) and Electronic Arts (EA) were rated as new overweight and new equal weight, respectively, at Wells Fargo.
  • ENERGY: Front-month oil futures are, on a relative to recent session basis, making tentative gains with both Brent and WTI up by less than a buck. The moves are likely some paring of the sell-off on Monday, in addition to positioning ahead of the much anticipated, and delayed, OPEC+ (plus) meeting on Thursday. Delegate reports intimate that Saudi and Russia are coming closer to an output deal; however, Russian press reports have subsequently pushed back on this stating all will be decided at Thursday’s meeting. Separates TASS sources have recently suggested the group could cut for three months starting in May, which saw some downside in crude futures in recent trade. Meanwhile, as OPEC+ calls publicly on North American commitments, US President Trump said that nobody has asked him to cut US output and that he will decide if OPEC asks the US to cut, while he added US producers had cut automatically as a reaction to the market; note, OPEC sources have doubled-down, saying the volume of reductions is dependent on the amount proposed by the US, Canada and Brazil.
  • TECHNICALS: BofA notes yesterday’s rally in the SPX brought it to a 38.2% retracement of the Feb-March decline (cash closed at ~2660). The bank notes the recent strength keeps the focus on a continued tactical bounce with focus next at 2792 (50% retracement) and 2881 (100-week MA), whereas it provides tactical supports at 2571/2522 (Monday’s upside gap), and below that at 2450, 2344/2300.

subject: Newsquawk Daily US Equity Opening News - 7th April 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

April 7th 2020

The Daily US Equity Opening News is uploaded at 1400BST/0800CDT recapping all the overnight equity news

  • Bill Ackman’s Pershing Square 2019 annual report: “increased our stakes in Agilent (A) by 16%, Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.B) by 39%, Hilton (HLT) by 34%, Howard Hughes (HHG) by 158%, Lowe’s (LOW) by 46%, and Restaurant Brands (QSR) by 26%. We have also reestablished a 10% of capital position in Starbucks (SBUX).”
  • Of note for Energy names (XOM, CVX, COP, OXY), President Trump last night stated he has not agreed to cut oil production as part of the OPEC+ deal and nor has anybody asked him to, adding US companies have already been cutting output given the current situation. However, the latest reports continue to state production cuts are needed from oil-producing nations, including the US.

DOW JONES

  • 3M Company (MMM) (Industrials/Industrial Conglomerates) and the Trump Administration have resolved their dispute. 3M announced a plan to import 166.5mln respirators over three months to help US health workers, and the Administration is working to address and remove export and regulatory restrictions to help with the plan.
  • Boeing Company (BA) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) announced it is to temporarily suspend its 787 operations at the South Carolina facility for the foreseeable future following April 8th.
  • Exxon Mobil Corp. (XOM) (Energy/Integrated Oil & Gas) cut 2020 Capex by 30% and cash Opex by 15%; maintained its long-term outlook. The largest share of Capex reductions will be in the Permian Basin. Expects to meet projected investments of USD 20bln on US Gulf Coast manufacturing facilities, expects to reach proposed US investments of USD 50bln over 5yrs announced in 2018. Mozambique project, expected later this year, has been postponed. Current operations onboard Liza Destiny production vessel are undisturbed. Capital allocation priorities remain unchanged. Long-term fundamentals that underpin Co’s business plans are unchanged. Globally, Co sees industry refinery output declining in-line with demand and storage available. CEO expects demand to fall 25-30% this year.
  • Merck & Co. (MRK) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals) announced it received US FDA priority review for a Keytruda treatment.

NASDAQ 100

  • Kraft Heinz Co (KHC) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) announced, after increased demand, sees Q1 net sales growth of +3% and +6% for its organic net sales growth, adding it does not expect the full benefit from incremental sales in Q1 to follow through to net income from cont. ops and EPS. CNBC highlight analysts were expecting a decline in sales.
  • Regeneron (REGN) (Health Care/Biotechnology) announced it has finalised an agreement with Sanofi (SAN FP), where REGN will not have sole responsibility for Praluent in the US, and Sanofi hold responsibility for it outside the US.

S&P 500

  • AT&T Inc. (T) (Communication Services/Integrated Telecommunication Services) announced a USD 5.5bln term loan agreement today at competitive rates with 12 banks to provided flexibility to an already strong cash position, and it will continue to pay quarterly dividends to shareholders.
  • AutoZone Inc (AZO) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Stores) announced it has temporarily suspended its share repurchase programme, offered workers time off benefit worth 80 hours to full-time employees and 40 hours to part-time. It also closed a new 364 day senior unsecured revolving credit facility worth USD 750mln.
  • D. R. Horton (DHI) (Consumer Discretionary/Homebuilding) announced it has withdrawn its FY20 guidance due to uncertainty surrounding the coronavirus, Q2 20 net sales +20% to 20,087 homes and +22% to USD 6.0bln in value. Q2 homes closed +8% to 14,539 homes and +10% to USD 4.4bln in value. Noted COVID-19 started to negatively impact its business operations during the latter part of March and into April.
  • Genuine Parts (GPC) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Stores) announced it has withdrawn FY20 guidance for FY20.
  • Global Payments Inc. (GPN) (Information Technology/Data Processing & Outsourced Services) announced it has withdrawn its FY20 guidance but announced it does not currently anticipate any significant operational impacts and January, February and the first two weeks of March beat its expectations, excluding a roughly USD 15mln adjusted net revenue impact of COVID-19. Therefore, it expects Q1 net revenue to be up slightly on combined bases and for EPS growth to be in the mid-teens Y/Y.
  • Macy’s Inc. (M) (Consumer Discretionary/Department Stores) announced its CFO Paula Price is to depart the company on May 31st.
  • Ralph Lauren Corporation (RL) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) announced it has furloughed most of its store employees.
  • Tractor Supply Company (TSCO) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Stores) announced it has withdrawn its FY20 guidance and temporarily suspended its share repurchase programme.
  • VF Corp. (VFC) (Consumer Discretionary/Apparel, Accessories & Luxury Goods) announced it will draw down the remaining USD 1bln from its unsecured revolving credit facility.

OTHER

  • Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) (Consumer Discretionary/Specialty Retail) announced it is furloughing its NA and EMEA store associates.
  • Alcon (ALC) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment & Supplies) announced it has withdrawn it is FY20 guidance and has delayed its dividend proposal to next year to save cash.
  • Continental Resources (CLR) (Energy, Oil, Gas & Consumable Fuels) announced it has suspended its quarterly cash dividends due to the coronavirus.
  • Cypress Semiconductor (CY) (Information Technology/Semiconductors & Semiconductor Equipment) announced its deal with Infineon Tech (IFNNY) received antitrust clearance from China, and now expects the merger to close around April 16th.
  • Hologic (HOLX) (Health Care/Health Care Equipment) Q2 20 (USD): Preliminary revenue 756.1mln (exp. 756.88mln). Notes disruptions had a significant negative impact on its late march sales and it has now withdrawn its FY20 guidance.
  • IAC (IAC) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) CEO wrote a letter which stated “we expect that revenue at about half of our companies will still grow this year, and revenue at half will decline”, but none of its businesses have seen a catastrophic shutdown in revenue. It also expects its new Match Group to be financially strong, generating significant cash with low capital expenditures.
  • Nio Inc (NIO) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) March deliveries: +116.8% M/M at 1533 vehicles.
  • Roku (ROKU) (Communication Services/Entertainment) announced its Roku Channel has arrived in the UK which holds access to 10k+ films, episodes, and documentaries.
  • Samsung (SSNLF) (Information Technology/Technology Hardware, Storage & Peripherals) Q120 (KRW) operating profit view 6.40tln (exp. 6.18trln). Q1 revenue view 55tln (exp. 55.35tln).
  • Slack (WORK) (Information Technology/Software) CEO announced it has seen an increase in new users and an increase of activity from existing users. It also increased the size of its convertible debt offering to USD 750mln (prev. USD 600mln).

PRIMER: FOMC Meeting Minutes to be released at 1400 ET/1900 BST on 8th April 2020
content:
• On the 3rd March, the Fed cut rates by 50bps in an emergency move. And then on 15th March weekend meeting, the Fed took further aggressive steps, slashing rates by 100bps to 0.25% in its second inter-meeting rate move; it also committed to at least USD 700bln of QE, eased regulatory pressure on banks to free up capital, and announced dollar swap lines with other central banks.
  • The timing of the both announcements and the scope of the measures was a surprise -- in effect, it was the Fed's 'whatever it takes' commitment to ensure the smooth functioning of markets amid the virus fallout.
  • NOTE: It is not clear whether the release of the minutes will cover both meetings, or just the latter; it is also unclear that if the minutes do cover both meetings, whether the release will be in two separate documents, or one aggregated one. Analysts at Nomura, however, have stated that the minutes will cover actions taken at both meetings.
  • Since then, it has flooded the market with liquidity, resulting in the premium for dollars easing. Its balance sheet has ballooned to by USD 1.5trln to a new record high USD 5.86trln, and it has seen wide take-up of its liquidity facilities from banks and other central banks.
  • The meeting minutes are unlikely to contain anything to spook markets, given that it has rolled-out measures to assuage market concerns, and will likely reiterate its pledge to support the financial system. Analysts think the discussions will likely show a most participants backing the use of the Fed's toolkit aggressively, as COVID-19 outbreak began weighing on activity.
  • The minutes may, however, feel stale. Since the 15th March meeting, the Fed has announced other measures (boosted QE and MBS purchases on 23/Mar, expanded repo for foreign central banks on 31/Mar, and also announced six further facilities, including the commercial paper facility). Discussions around these themes will likely appear in the next meeting minutes for the 28-29th April meeting, analysts believe.
  • NOTE: Fed Chair Powell will be delivering remarks via weblink on Thursday, and will likely emphasise the themes within the minutes.

subject: OPEC+: HEADLINE RECAP [UPDATED]
content:
OPEC+

  • The OPEC+ meeting is due to take place at on Thursday at 1500BST, with a presser to follow (all times tentative) – OPEC+ press conference tends to be delayed
  • G20 ministers to convene an extraordinary meeting on Friday (at 1300BST), to discuss the energy market turmoil, according to reports. Energy Intel notes of a meeting on Friday in which members outside OPEC+ will be asked pledge additional reductions, “over and above 10mln BPD” - Russia will partake in both meetings according to sources
  • OPEC+ group is reportedly likely to agree to oil production cuts on Thursday although it is contingent upon the US joining in with the production cuts, according to three OPEC+ sources. Earlier reports noted OPEC+ still can't reach a preliminary consensus on individual volumes of oil production cuts, particularly the largest producers, according to three delegations cited by TASS

TOUTED CUTS

  • OPEC+ is discussing an output cut for three months, beginning in May, according to TASS
  • OPEC+ oil cut volume for Thursday's meeting is dependent on the amount US, Canada, Brazil and others propose to cut, according to OPEC sources; notes, the baseline for oil cuts is yet to be agreed upon
  • Under one of the touted OPEC+ scenarios: 10mln BPD cuts will include North America; Saudi would cut a minimum of 3mln BPD; Russia 1.5mln BPD; Non-Saudi Gulf 1.5mln BPD; US, Canada, and Brazil almost 2mln BPD (Texas at least 500k BPD) according to sources cited by WSJ’s Summer Said.

SAUDI

  • Saudi Arabia is reportedly considering an oil output cut beneath 9mln BPD if others were to join in, according to WSJ citing sources
  • Saudi Aramco delayed its May OSP release until after the OPEC+ meeting, touted to be released on 10th April
  • Saudi increased oil supply in April to above 12mln BPD, in-fitting with prior sources
  • Saudi Official said if there is no deal, we will have some nice number of floating tankers going nowhere, according to a Saudi official

RUSSIA

  • Russian producers are reportedly ready for oil cuts in order to stop the price rout, where the industry may agree to cuts if US and Saudi joins
  • Russia is not likely to agree to output cuts if US does not also curb production, according to sources cited by WSJ's Summer Said
  • Russia and Saudi Arabia are reportedly 'very, very close' to a deal on oil production cuts, according to Dmitriev the CEO of RDIF
  • Saudi Arabia and Russia are reportedly coming closer to an agreement on an output deal, according to delegates but there reportedly is no consensus between Russia and Saudi Arabia as of yet, all will be decided at Thursday's OPEC+ meeting, according to RIA's Novosti
  • Russia held off on hiking output in April amid the supply glut
  • Russian Energy Minister Novak said current oil price is not satisfying for anyone, but Moscow can survive through a period of low prices

US

  • US President Trump said he did not make concessions during talks with Saudi and Russia on oil, while he did not agree to a US domestic production cut
  • US President Trump said nobody has asked him to cut US oil output and that he will decide if OPEC asks US to cut production, adding that US producers have cut back automatically as a reaction to the market
  • US independent oil producers reportedly told OPEC they will voluntarily cut output
  • US oil majors worry about antitrust issues if they join OPEC+ cuts
  • Texas Railroad Commissioner Sitton said he doesn't see the US having a long relationship with OPEC at all and that Texas would agree to oil production curbs if President Trump reaches an international agreement

OTHERS

  • Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Colombia, Egypt, Indonesia, Norway, the UK, the US, and Trinidad & Tobago have been invited to take part in Thursday’s meeting, according to OPEC delegates cited by Energy Intel
  • Saudis and Russia have called for other global producers – namely the US, Canada, and Mexico – to share the burden of cuts
  • Norwegian Oil Ministry state they were invited to the OPEC; would consider partaking as an observer if there was broad participation - adds there are no ongoing talks with oil Co's on cuts
  • UAE’s Adnoc and Kuwait have delayed their May OSP releases until after the OPEC+ meeting

Newsquawk Daily US Opening News - 7th April 2020
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Sentiment remains bolstered from the APAC lead, as US equity futures extend on gains
  • Delegate reports intimate that Saudi and Russia are coming closer to an output deal; however, Russian press reports have subsequently pushed back on this
  • Japanese PM Abe declares a State of Emergency in 7 prefectures as expected; Gov’t has approved JPY 108.2trl in stimulus
  • RBA kept rates on hold at 0.25% as expected and the board reaffirmed the 3yr yield target at 0.25%
  • FX sees the DXY softer, to the benefit of all major counterparts – particularly antipodeans
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US JOLTS, EIA STEO, APIs, Eurogroup Meeting, supply from the US

CORONAVIRUS UPDATE

US President Trump said we have made tremendous progress on therapeutics and have contacted UK PM Johnson's doctors, while he added that the administration wants to try to be able to lift restrictions on April 30th. President Trump said businesses applied for more than USD 40bln in relief loans, that USD 30bln in hospital aid is going out this week and that they could very well do a 2nd round of direct payments to Americans. (Newswires)

US House Speaker Pelosi told Democrats she wants the next virus bill to be at least USD 1tln, while she is said to be seeking more directs payments and small business loans in the next bill. (Newswires)

AFP tweeted that the US record 1150 coronavirus deaths citing the Johns Hopkins tracker. (AFP)

Mainland China reported 32 additional coronavirus cases and 0 new deaths on April 6th vs. 39 new cases and 1 death on April 5th, to bring the total number of cases in the mainland to 81470 and death toll remained at 3331. (Newswires)

Italy could reportedly begin the gradual end of the lockdown period by May 4th, according to Corriere. (Corriere Della Sera)

German Economy Minster Altmaier says there is not enough data to support the loosening of restrictions, and companies must very soon be able to recommence output. (Newswires) Germany's Robert Koch Institute says we are not at the stage yet we can talk about an easing of cases yet and we need to wait and see what happens in the coming days. (Newswires)

Japanese PM Abe declares a State of Emergency in Tokyo, Osaka, alongside five other prefectures for one month amid coronavirus; additionally, Japanese government has approved the JPY 108.2trl emergency economic stimulus package with JPY 39.5trl spending; as expected. Separately, Tokyo has over 80 new cases of COVID-19, according to NHK. (Newswires/NHK)

Spanish coronavirus cases 140,510 (Prev. 135,032) and deaths stand at 13,798 ( +743; Prev. 13,055). (Newswires)

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly higher as the region took impetus from the considerable pick up on Wall St where all major indices finished higher by at least 7.0% and the DJIA notched a more than 1600-point gain amid hopes of a slowdown in the coronavirus outbreak after encouraging numbers from various hot spots, although some economists warned caution given that the economy was far from out of the woods and the latest reports suggested the daily death toll in the US remained at an alarming level of 1150 according to the Johns Hopkins tracker. ASX 200 (-0.7%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.0%) were both boosted and surged over 2% shortly after the open although gains in Australia then waned amid losses in the healthcare sector and cautiousness heading into the RBA decision, while the Japanese benchmark briefly broke above the 19000 level supported by better than expected Housing Spending data and plans for a JPY 108tln package but later gave back a majority of gains heading into the state of emergency declaration. Hang Seng (+2.1%) and Shanghai Comp. (+2.1%) were also positive with outperformance seen in the mainland as it plays catch up on return from the extended weekend and took its first opportunity to react to the PBoC’s 100bps targeted RRR cut announcement. Finally, 10yr JGBs were higher as prices bounced back from support around the 152.00 level and with the BoJ offering to buy JPY 150bln of corporate bonds, although upside was also capped due to the mostly upbeat risk tone and following weaker results at the 30yr JGB auction.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 70bln. (Newswires) PBoC set USD/CNY mid-point at 7.0939 vs. Exp. 7.0915 (Prev. 7.1104)

Japanese All Household Spending (Feb) M/M 0.8% vs. Exp. -0.2% (Prev. -1.6%). (Newswires) Japanese All Household Spending (Feb) Y/Y -0.3% vs. Exp. -3.9% (Prev. -3.9%)

UK/EU

German Ifo Institute: states that industrial production in Germany is set to plummet - Ifo index for production expectations dropped in March from +2.0 to -20.8, on this they assume the development is underestimated given the survey period; the most drastic slump since the survey began. (Newswires)

US

EQUITIES

European stocks post another straight session of gains in early trade [Euro Stoxx 50 +3.5%], following a mostly positive APAC handover, as participants see optimism on the COVID-19 containments front and heading into the Eurogroup meeting on Finance Ministers, in which three stimulus measures are expected to be discussed (Primer available here). Broad-based gains are seen across the major European bourses, whilst Italy’s FTSE MIB (+5.2%) outperforms in the periphery, with the index’s large financial sector benefitting from price action in the fixed income complex – and as the region feels tailwinds from the ECB allocating a lion’s share of its bond-buying (35%) to Italian debt in March. Sectors are all in positive territory and reflect a “risk-on” mood, with cyclicals outpacing defensives, Financials benefit from the high-yield environment. The theme of today is a sharp rebound across stocks and sectors that have been decimated on the COVID-19 outbreak. The sector breakdown sees Travel & Leisure notably outperforming, whilst Auto names follow a close second. Thus, easyJet (+18.9%), Carnival (+18.8%) among the top gainers in the region, whilst aircraft engine makers Rolls Royce (+14.0%) and Safran (+9.0%) also see gains in excess of 10%, having recently been hit on the prospects of declining aircraft productions on lower demand. On the flip side, Healthcare names are softer given the sector’s relative buoyancy during the demise of riskier stocks – AstraZeneca (-1.8%), Novo Nordisk (-1.5%).

FX

DXY - The Dollar is softer across the board amidst another upturn in sentiment on the hope that tentative signs of COVID-19 curve flattening do not prove short-lived and completely dashed by Tuesday’s global updates on the state of the virus. The DXY has retreated a bit further from recent recovery highs just shy of 101.000 as a result and is now hovering a fraction above 100.000 with little in the way of technical support before March 31’s high (99.948) to supplement the obvious psychological props.

AUD/NZD - The Aussie is outperforming after the RBA maintained rates overnight and offered some exit policy guidance, albeit somewhat premature at this still very formative stage. However, bolstered by the aforementioned less downbeat risk tone Aud/Usd has built on advances through 0.6150 and got to within a whisker of 0.6200 before running out of momentum, while Aud/Nzd has crossed 1.0300 as the Kiwi failed to sustain 0.6000+ status in wake of NZIER sentiment sinking in Q1 and ahead of latest bi-weekly GDT auction results.

NOK/GBP/EUR - The Norwegian Crown looks all set to extend its bull run against the backdrop of firm oil prices in the run up to Thursday’s OPEC+ meeting that Russia will attend and is reportedly nearing an agreement with Saudi Arabia about how many bpd to cut in order to stabilise the cost of crude. Eur/Nok has been down to circa 11.1060 even though the single currency has unwound declines vs the Buck at 1.0880 from sub-1.0800. Elsewhere, the Pound has also regrouped after depreciation on news of UK PM Johnson’s transfer to intensive care pushed Cable down to around 1.2165, but hit resistance into 1.2350 and is still below 0.8800 in Euro cross terms.

CHF/CAD/JPY - The Franc is back near up the top of a 0.9725-95 or so range after SNB reserves data showing a fall in stark contrast to weekly Swiss sight deposits supporting the notion that intervention has picked up markedly of late, with little reaction to rises in jobless rates that are likely to pale in comparison to increases in unemployment to come. Similarly, the Loonie has pared post-BoC business outlook survey losses with the aid of buoyancy in oil to retest 1.4000 ahead of Canada’s Ivey PMI and awaiting the nation’s contribution to the joint crude output cut, assuming there is consensus. Meanwhile, the Yen has also profited at the Greenback’s expense, though to a lesser extent as a renowned safe-haven and with Japan confirming 7 prefectures in an official state of emergency, including Tokyo. Usd/Jpy is currently pivoting 109.00, but from a chart perspective still on an upward trajectory while above the 200 DMA (108.34) and not likely to stir hefty option expiry interest from 108.00 to 108.50 rolling off on Wednesday unless things change quite dramatically in the next 24 hours of course.

EM - Widespread rebounds vs the Dollar, and with the Rand unwinding more of its significant underperformance through 18.3000 vs 19.3500 at the other extreme due to consolidation and short covering more than anything fundamental, aside from the broad improvement in risk sentiment.

RBA kept rates on hold at 0.25% as expected and the board reaffirmed the 3yr yield target at 0.25% which is expected to remain in place until progress is being made towards goals of full employment and inflation. RBA added the board is committed to doing what it can to support jobs, incomes and businesses as Australia deals with the coronavirus but noted that once the virus is contained, a recovery in the global economy is expected. Furthermore, it stated that if conditions continue to improve, it is likely that smaller less frequent purchases of government bonds will be needed. (Newswires)

Australian Trade Balance (AUD)(Feb) 4361mln vs. Exp. 3650mln (Prev. 5210mln). (Newswires) Australian Exports (Feb) M/M -5% (Prev. -3.0%) Australian Imports (Feb) M/M -4% (Prev. -3.0%)

FIXED

It seems that bearish momentum rather than anything new or more negative has prompted the latest downturn in 10 year German debt as another notable chart support in the guise of the 100 DMA (171.05) has been breached on the way down to a fresh 170.91 intraday Eurex low. Indeed, linker supply was absorbed well enough, albeit demand mixed vs previous sales and average yields less negative, while the charge in EU stocks has abated somewhat. Moreover, Gilts are still holding above 136.00 after a marginally closer look, at 136.03 before an even bigger bounce to 136.30 and 10 year T-notes are a fraction off their overnight session base ahead of JOLTS and Usd25 bn supply in that tenor.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent front-month futures have resumed their rise in the run-up to a “make or break” OPEC+ meeting, with members outside the group urged to join in on a potential coordinated move. In terms of where we stand, the OPEC+ meeting is due to take place at on Thursday at 1500BST, with a presser to follow (all times tentative) – OPEC+ press conferences tend to be delayed. Reports also noted that G20 ministers to convene an extraordinary meeting on Friday at 1300BST, to discuss the energy market turmoil, according to reports. Energy Intel notes of a meeting on Friday in which members outside OPEC+ will be asked pledge additional reductions, “over and above 10mln BPD”. OPEC sources stated that OPEC+ group is reportedly likely to agree to oil production cuts on Thursday although it is contingent upon the US joining in with the production cuts, according to three OPEC+ sources. That said, earlier reports intimated OPEC+ still can't reach a preliminary consensus on individual volumes of oil production cuts, particularly the largest producers, according to three delegations cited by TASS. As a reminder, under one of the touted OPEC+ scenarios: 10mln BPD cuts will include North America; Saudi would cut a minimum of 3mln BPD; Russia 1.5mln BPD; US, Canada, and Brazil almost 2mln BPD (Texas at least 500k BPD) according to sources cited by WSJ’s Summer Said. Furthermore, today will see the release of the first monthly oil report, the EIA STEO, which will depict a clear impact of the coronavirus outbreak – thus eyes will be on the magnitude of further demand downgrades and revisions lower to US crude output as a function of lower oil prices. That being said, the release may be overshadowed by the tentative OPEC+ congregation later in the week, which will shift the dynamic in the oil market. In terms of data, the weekly API releases at the usual time, with forecasts for a headline build of around 9mln barrels over the last week. WTI May’20 hovers around USD 27/bbl (vs. low of USD 26.29/bbl, and high USD 27.19), whilst its Brent counterpart re-eyes USD 34/bbl to the upside having briefly breached the level during late APAC trade. Elsewhere, spot gold fails to benefit from the weaker Buck, as the rise in equities proves the yellow metal to be less attractive, with prices back below 1650/oz after rising to a whisker away from 1680/oz in the overnight session. Meanwhile, copper prices continue to mimic the rise in stocks, with the red metal piggybacking overall risk appetite and breaking out of its recent range (USD 2-2.25lb), with red metal prices around USD 2.3/lb at the time of writing.

US President Trump commented that nobody has asked him to cut US oil output and that he will decide if OPEC asks US to cut production, while he added US producers have cut automatically as a reaction to the market. (Newswires)

Delegate reports intimate that Saudi and Russia are coming closer to an output deal; however, Russian press reports have subsequently pushed back on this stating all will be decided at Thursday’s meeting. (Newswires)

OPEC+ oil cut volume for Thursday's meeting is dependent on the amount US, Canada, Brazil and others propose to cut, according to OPEC sources; notes, the baseline for oil cuts is yet to be agreed upon. (Newswires)

Russia has reportedly agreed to partake in Friday's G20 call between energy ministers, sources state. (Newswires)

CME raised crude oil NYMEX margins by 5.5% to USD 6700/contract from USD 6350/contract. (Newswires)

subject: UK sells GBP 1.25bln 1.75% 2057 with a b/c 3.13x (Prev. b/c. 2.25x), average yield 0.719% (Prev. 1.629%) and tail 0.2bps (Prev. 0.1bps)
Swiss coronavirus cases stand at 22,242 deaths at 641, according to the Gov't

subject: OPEC+: HEADLINE RECAP [UPDATED]
content:
OPEC+

  • The OPEC+ meeting is due to take place at on Thursday at 1500BST, with a presser to follow (all times tentative) – OPEC+ press conference tends to be delayed
  • G20 ministers to convene an extraordinary meeting on Friday (at 1300BST), to discuss the energy market turmoil, according to reports. Energy Intel notes of a meeting on Friday in which members outside OPEC+ will be asked pledge additional reductions, “over and above 10mln BPD” - Russia will partake in both meetings according to sources
  • OPEC+ group is reportedly likely to agree to oil production cuts on Thursday although it is contingent upon the US joining in with the production cuts, according to three OPEC+ sources. Earlier reports noted OPEC+ still can't reach a preliminary consensus on individual volumes of oil production cuts, particularly the largest producers, according to three delegations cited by TASS
  • OPEC+ oil cut volume for Thursday's meeting is dependent on the amount US, Canada, Brazil and others propose to cut, according to OPEC sources; notes, the baseline for oil cuts is yet to be agreed upon
  • Under one of the touted OPEC+ scenarios: 10mln BPD cuts will include North America; Saudi would cut a minimum of 3mln BPD; Russia 1.5mln BPD; Non-Saudi Gulf 1.5mln BPD; US, Canada, and Brazil almost 2mln BPD (Texas at least 500k BPD) according to sources cited by WSJ’s Summer Said.

SAUDI

  • Saudi Arabia is reportedly considering an oil output cut beneath 9mln BPD if others were to join in, according to WSJ citing sources
  • Saudi Aramco delayed its May OSP release until after the OPEC+ meeting, touted to be released on 10th April
  • Saudi increased oil supply in April to above 12mln BPD, in-fitting with prior sources
  • Saudi Official said if there is no deal, we will have some nice number of floating tankers going nowhere, according to a Saudi official

RUSSIA

  • Russian producers are reportedly ready for oil cuts in order to stop the price rout, where the industry may agree to cuts if US and Saudi joins
  • Russia is not likely to agree to output cuts if US does not also curb production, according to sources cited by WSJ's Summer Said
  • Russia and Saudi Arabia are reportedly 'very, very close' to a deal on oil production cuts, according to Dmitriev the CEO of RDIF
  • Saudi Arabia and Russia are reportedly coming closer to an agreement on an output deal, according to delegates but there reportedly is no consensus between Russia and Saudi Arabia as of yet, all will be decided at Thursday's OPEC+ meeting, according to RIA's Novosti
  • Russia held off on hiking output in April amid the supply glut
  • Russian Energy Minister Novak said current oil price is not satisfying for anyone, but Moscow can survive through a period of low prices

US

  • US President Trump said he did not make concessions during talks with Saudi and Russia on oil, while he did not agree to a US domestic production cut
  • US President Trump said nobody has asked him to cut US oil output and that he will decide if OPEC asks US to cut production, adding that US producers have cut back automatically as a reaction to the market
  • US independent oil producers reportedly told OPEC they will voluntarily cut output
  • US oil majors worry about antitrust issues if they join OPEC+ cuts
  • Texas Railroad Commissioner Sitton said he doesn't see the US having a long relationship with OPEC at all and that Texas would agree to oil production curbs if President Trump reaches an international agreement

OTHERS

  • Argentina, Brazil, Canada, Colombia, Egypt, Indonesia, Norway, the UK, the US, and Trinidad & Tobago have been invited to take part in Thursday’s meeting, according to OPEC delegates cited by Energy Intel
  • Saudis and Russia have called for other global producers – namely the US, Canada, and Mexico – to share the burden of cuts
  • Norwegian Oil Ministry state they were invited to the OPEC; would consider partaking as an observer if there was broad participation - adds there are no ongoing talks with oil Co's on cuts
  • UAE’s Adnoc and Kuwait have delayed their May OSP releases until after the OPEC+ meeting
